contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox website | name = ''MathWorld'' | logo = [[File:MathWorld logo.gif|alt=Logo of MathWorld]]<!-- [[File:MathWorldLogo.JPG|250px|alt=Logo of MathWorld]] --> | logocaption = | screenshot = | caption = | collapsible = | caption = | url = {{URL|http://mathworld.wolfram.com|mathworld.wolfram.com}} | type of organization = [[Privately held Company|Private]] | location = | type = [[Internet encyclopedia project]] | language = [[English language|English]] | registration = Not required for viewing | owner = [[Wolfram Research, Inc.]] ([[for-profit]]) | author = [[Eric W. Weisstein]]<ref name="Making">{{cite journal |title=Making MathWorld |author=Eric Weisstein |journal=Mathematica Journal |volume=10 |issue=3 |year=2007 |url=http://www.mathematica-journal.com/issue/v10i3/MathWorld.html}}</ref> and other contributors | launch date = {{Start date and years ago|mf=yes|1999|11|0}}{{dubious|reason=There's no such date as November 0 - that would be October 31, but I'm not sure if this is a typo for some other date in November|date=April 2011}} (available at another location since 1995<ref name=faq-history>{{cite web|title=What is the history of MathWorld?|work=MathWorld Q&A|url=http://mathworld.wolfram.com/about/faq.html#history|publisher=[[Wolfram Research, Inc.]]|accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref>) | commercial = Yes | alexa = <!-- {{increase}} 7 ({{As of|February 2011}})<ref name="AlexaStats" /> --> | current status = Active | slogan = "the web's most extensive mathematics resource" | content license = [[All rights reserved]] (copyright held by contributors and non-exclusively licensed to [[Wolfram Research, Inc.]]<!-- HTML: <meta name="DC.Rights" content="Copyright Wolfram Research, Inc." />-->, free for personal and educational use)<ref name=faq-copyright>{{cite web|title=Is the material on MathWorld copyrighted?|work=MathWorld Q&A|url=http://mathworld.wolfram.com/about/faq.html#copyright|publisher=[[Wolfram Research, Inc.]]|accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref><ref>http://mathworld.wolfram.com/about/terms.html</ref> }} '''''MathWorld''''' is an online [[mathematics]] reference work, created and largely written by [[Eric W. Weisstein]]. It is sponsored by and licensed to [[Wolfram Research, Inc.]] and was partially funded by the [[National Science Foundation]]'s [[National Science Digital Library]] grant to the [[University of Illinois at Urbanaâ€“Champaign]]. ==History== Eric W. Weisstein, the creator of the site, was a [[physics]] and [[astronomy]] student who got into the habit of writing notes on his mathematical readings. In 1995 he put his notes online and called it "Eric's Treasure Trove of Mathematics". It contained hundreds of pages/articles, covering a wide range of mathematical topics. The site became popular as an extensive single resource on mathematics on the web. Weisstein continuously improved the notes and accepted corrections and comments from online readers. In 1998, he made a contract with [[CRC Press]] and the contents of the site were published in print and [[CD-ROM]], titled "CRC Concise Encyclopedia of Mathematics". The free online version became only partially accessible to the public. In 1999 Weisstein went to work for [[Wolfram Research]], Inc. (WRI), and WRI renamed the Math Treasure Trove to ''MathWorld'' at http://mathworld.wolfram.com and hosted it on the company's website without access restrictions. ==CRC lawsuit== In 2000, [[CRC Press]] sued WRI, WRI president [[Stephen Wolfram]], and author Eric Weisstein, due to what they considered a breach of contract: that the ''MathWorld'' content was to remain in print only. The site was taken down by a court injunction. The case was later settled out of court, with WRI paying an unspecified<!--?--> amount and complying with other [[stipulation|stipulations]]. Among these stipulations is the inclusion of a copyright notice at the bottom of the website and broad rights for the CRC Press to produce ''MathWorld'' in printed book form. The site then became once again available free to the public. This case made a wave of headlines in online publishing circles. The ''[[PlanetMath]]'' project was a result of MathWorld's being unavailable. ==See also== *[[Eric W. Weisstein]] *[[PlanetMath]] *[[List of online encyclopedias]] *[[Mathematica]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links== *{{Official website|http://www.mathworld.wolfram.com/}} [[Category:Mathematics websites]] [[Category:Educational websites]] [[Category:Online encyclopedias]] [[Category:Mathematics education]] [[Category:Wolfram Research|Mathworld]]
